sn16.6:1.1: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.
sn16.6:1.2: Then Venerable Mahākassapa went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
sn16.6:1.5: Either you or I should advise the mendicants
sn16.6:1.6: and give them a Dhamma talk.”
sn16.6:2.1: “Sir, the mendicants these days are hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.
sn16.6:2.2: Take the monk named Bhaṇḍa, Ānanda’s protégé. He’s been competing in studies with the monk named Abhiñjika, Anuruddha’s protégé. They say:
sn16.6:2.3: ‘Come on, monk, who can speak more? Who can speak better? Who can speak longer?’”
sn16.6:3.1: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
sn16.6:3.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell the monk called Bhaṇḍa, Ānanda’s protégé, and the monk called Abhiñjika, Anuruddha’s protégé that
sn16.6:3.4: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those monks and said,
sn16.6:4.1: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:
sn16.6:4.2: “Is it really true, monks, that you’ve been competing in studies, saying:
sn16.6:4.3: ‘Come on, monk, who can speak more? Who can speak better? Who can speak longer?’”
sn16.6:4.5: “Have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma like this:
sn16.6:4.7: see who can recite more and better and longer’?”
sn16.6:4.9: “If you’ve never known me to teach the Dhamma like this, what then do you know and see, you futile men, that after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training you’d compete in studies to
sn16.6:4.10: see who can speak more and better and longer?”
sn16.6:5.1: Then those monks bowed with their heads at the Buddha’s feet and said,
sn16.6:5.2: “We have made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of us in that after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training we competed in studies to
sn16.6:5.3: see who can speak more and better and longer.
sn16.6:5.4: Please, sir, accept our mistake for what it is, so we will restrain ourselves in future.”
sn16.6:6.1: “Indeed, monks, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to act in that way.
sn16.6:6.3: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
sn16.6:6.4: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”
